definition: A concentrated form of coffee served in small, strong shots. It's made by forcing pressurized hot water through very finely ground coffee beans.
An espresso-based drink that consists of equal parts espresso, steamed milk, and milk foam.
A coffee drink made with espresso and steamed milk, topped with a small layer of milk foam.
A drink made by adding hot water to espresso, giving it a similar strength to, but different flavor from, regular drip coffee.
An espresso with a small amount of foamed milk on top.
Coffee made by steeping coarse grounds in cold water for an extended period, usually 12-24 hours.
A coffee brewing device in which coarsely ground coffee is steeped in hot water and then separated from the grounds by pressing a mesh plunger through the pot.
The layer of tan-colored foam that sits on top of a freshly brewed shot of espresso.
The process of heating coffee beans to develop their flavor. Common roast levels include light, medium, and dark.
A person who prepares and serves coffee drinks, typically in a coffee shop.
The stage in coffee roasting when beans begin to pop and expand, releasing water vapor and CO2. It signifies the beginning of light roast development.
A later stage in coffee roasting, characterized by a more subtle crackling sound. It indicates the beginning of dark roast development and oil emergence on the bean surface.
A professional tasting technique used to evaluate the aroma and flavor profile of a coffee.
The process of measuring the correct amount of ground coffee for brewing, typically for espresso preparation.
The act of compressing ground coffee in an espresso portafilter to create resistance for water flow during extraction.
A handled basket that holds ground coffee for espresso brewing, which attaches to the group head of an espresso machine.
The part of an espresso machine where the portafilter is attached and through which hot water is dispensed for brewing.
A type of coffee grinder that uses two revolving abrasive surfaces (burrs) to grind coffee beans, resulting in uniform particle size.
A type of burr grinder with a cone-shaped center burr, known for producing consistent grinds and generating less heat.
A type of burr grinder with two parallel rings of burrs, known for producing very uniform grinds ideal for espresso.
Finely textured milk with small, uniform bubbles, created during the steaming process for drinks like lattes and cappuccinos.
The initial phase of milk steaming where air is introduced to create foam.
The process of heating and aerating milk to create a smooth, velvety consistency for use in espresso-based drinks.
A cleaning process for espresso machines where water is forced backwards through the group head to remove coffee oils and residue.
The process of removing mineral buildup from inside an espresso machine or other coffee equipment using a descaling solution.
The act of running water or steam through an espresso machine's group head or steam wand to clean it between uses.
The process of adjusting various parameters (grind size, dose, tamp pressure) to achieve the optimal espresso extraction.
The process of dissolving desirable flavors from coffee grounds into water during brewing.
When too much is taken from the coffee grounds, resulting in bitter, astringent flavors.
When too little is taken from the coffee grounds, resulting in sour, weak, and underdeveloped flavors.
